abstract.text: An abstract base class for managing discrete portions of your app's data.
Schedules a document-reading or document-writing operation on a concurrent background queue.
Reverts a document to the most recent document data stored on-disk.
The file URL with which the document was initialized.
Returns whether the document has any unsaved changes.
The undo manager for the document.
Update the change counter by indicating the kind of change.
Returns the current state of the document.
Posted by the document object when there is a change in the state of the document.
Opens a document asynchronously.
Asynchronously closes the document after saving any changes.
Saves document data to the specified location in the application sandbox.
Called or overridden to handle an error that occurs during an attempt to read, save, or revert a document.
Override this method to return the document data to be saved.
Override this method to load the document data into the app’s data model.
Reads the document data in a file at a specified location in the application sandbox.
Writes the document data to disk at the sandbox location indicated by a file URL.
Ensures that document data is written safely to a specified location in the application sandbox.
Returns the file type to use for saving a document.
The file type of the document.
A managed document object that integrates with Core Data.
Returns a document object initialized with its file-system location.
The localized name of the document.
The date and time the document file was last modified.
The upload or download progress of a document.
Returns a dictionary of file attributes to associate with the document file when writing or updating it.
Returns a file extension to append to the file URL of the document file being written.
Overridden to disable editing when it is unsafe to make changes to a document.
Overridden to enable editing when it is safe again to make changes to a document.
Overridden to return a change token for a specific save operation.
Overridden to update the change count with reference to a change-count token passed in by UIKit.
Called by UIKit to initiate automatic saving of documents with unsaved changes.
An object encapsulating a user activity supported by this document.
Restores the state needed to continue the given user activity.
Updates the state of the given user activity.
Tells UIKit that you have finished handled the error.
Sent when it is no longer safe to proceed without immediately handling the error.
Constants for specifying the kind of change to a document.
Constants for specifying the type of save operation.
The document state.
The key that identifies the document associated with a user activity.
An abstract base class for managing discrete portions of your app's data.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Synchronizing Documents in the iCloud Environment

abstract.text: Manage documents across multiple devices to create a seamless editing and collaboration experience.

inlineContent.text: Applications that make use of
and its underlying architecture get many benefits for their documents:
Asynchronous reading and writing of data on a background queue. Your application's responsiveness to users is thus unaffected while reading and writing operations are taking place.
Coordinated reading and writing of document files that is automatically integrated with cloud services.
Support for discovering conflicts between different versions of a document (if that occurs).
Safe-saving of document data by writing data first to a temporary file and then replacing the current document file with it.
Automatic saving of document data at opportune moments; this mechanism includes support for dealing with suspend behaviors.
In the Model-View-Controller design pattern, a

object is a model object or model-controller object—it manages the data of a document or the aggregate model objects that together constitute the document's data. You typically pair it with a view controller that manages the view presenting the document’s contents.
provides no support for managing document views.
Document-based applications include those that can generate multiple documents, each with its own file-system location.  A document-based application must create a subclass of
for its documents. See “Subclassing Notes,” below, for details.
If you are using a database to store document data, create a subclass of the
class instead of
is a subclass of
The primary attribute of a document in the
architecture is its file URL. When you initialize an instance of your document subclass by calling
, you must pass a file URL locating the document file in the application sandbox.

determines the file type (the Uniform Type Identifier associated with the file extension) and the document name (the filename component) from the file URL. You can override the accessor methods of the
and
properties to supply different values.
The following outlines the life cycle of a typical document (see “Subclassing Notes” for implementation details):
You create a new document or open an existing document.
To create a new document, allocate and initialize an instance of your subclass and then call
on the instance.
To open an existing document (selected by the user), allocate and initialize an instance of your subclass and then call
on the instance.
The user edits the document.
As the user edits, track changes to the document.
periodically notes when there are unsaved changes and writes the document data to its file.
The user requests that the document to be integrated with cloud services (optional).
You must enable the document for cloud storage. You must also resolve any conflicts between different versions of the same document.
The user closes the document.
Call
on the document instance.
saves the document if there are any unsaved changes.
A typical document-based application calls
, and

on the main thread. When the read or save operation kicked off by these methods concludes, the completion-handler block is executed on the same dispatch queue on which the method was invoked, allowing you to complete any tasks contingent on the read or save operation. If the operation is not successful,
is passed into the completion-hander block.
The
class adopts the
protocol. When another client attempts to read the document of a
-based application, that reading is suspended until the
object is given an opportunity to save any changes made to the document.
Although some implementations do nothing,
implements all
methods. Specifically,

to forward the incoming block to
Implements
to check if the file-modification date has changed; if the file is newer than before, it calls
with the value of the
as the URL parameter.

to update the document’s file URL (
In your
subclass, if you override a
method you can always invoke the superclass implementation (
Each document-based application must create a subclass of
whose instances represent its documents. The subclassing requirements for most applications are simple:
For writing operations, implement the
method to provide a snapshot of document data. The data must be in the form of an
object (for flat files) or an
object (for file packages). Writing operations are usually initiated through the autosave feature
For reading operations, implement the
method to receives an
or
object and initialize the application's data structures with it.
Implement change tracking to enable the autosaving feature. See
for details.
When cloud services are enabled for a document, resolve conflicts between different versions of a document. See
for details.
The
and
methods are typically called on the main queue. More specifically:
The
method is called on the queue that the
method was called on; writing of data takes place on a background thread
The
method is called on the queue that the
method was called on
If you have special requirements for reading and writing document data for which the
and
methods won’t suffice, you can override other methods of the
class. See
for a discussion of these requirements and methods.
To enable the autosaving feature of
, you must notify it when users make changes to a document.
periodically checks whether the
method returns
; if it does, it initiates the save operation for the document.
There are two primary ways to implement change tracking in your
subclass:
Call the methods of the
class to implement undo and redo for the document. You can access the default
object from the
property. This is the preferred approach, especially for existing applications that already support undo and redo.
Call the
method at the appropriate junctures in your code.
A
object has a specific state at any moment in its life cycle. You can check the current state by querying the
property, and get notified about changes by observing the
notification.
If a document is enabled for iCloud, it is important to check for conflicting versions and to attempt to resolve conflicts. Do this by listening for the
notification and then checking if the document state is
. This state indicates that there are conflicting versions of the document, which you can access by calling the
class method

, passing in the document’s file URL. If you can resolve a conflict correctly without user interaction, do so. Otherwise, discretely notify the user that a conflict exists and let them choose how to resolve it. Possible approaches include:
Displaying the conflicting versions, from which a user can pick one or both versions to keep
Displaying a merged version and giving the user an option to pick it
Displaying the file modification dates and giving the user the option to choose one or both
Document state, in addition to indicating an inter-file conflict, can indicate errors. For example,
indicates an error in reading, and
indicates an error in saving or reverting a document. Your app is notified of reading and writing errors through the
parameter passed into the completion handlers of the
, and
methods.
You can handle errors by calling or implementing the
method; this method is called by the default implementations of the
and
methods when a
object encounters a reading or writing error, respectively. You can handle read, save, and reversion errors by informing the user and, if the situation permits, trying to recover from the error.
Be sure to read the description for the
method for its guidance on handling errors encountered during document saving.
If you application has special requirements for reading or writing document data, it can override methods of
other than
and
. These requirements often include the following:
Incremental reading and writing of large data files
Override the
and
methods, respectively
Custom representations of document data (that is, not a
or
object)
Override the
method (when reading document data) and the
method (when writing document data).
Performing actions before or after reading or writing data
Override
and
A custom approach to safe-saving
Override the
method.
Changing the file type of a document before it’s saved
Override the
method to return a file type other than the default (
). An example of this is an RTF document which, after a user adds an image to it, should be saved as an RTFD document.

If you override most of these methods be aware that all reading and writing of document data must be done on a background queue and must be coordinated with other attempts to read from and write to the same document file. Because of this, you should usually call the superclass implementation (
) as part of your override, and if you call other
methods you should usually invoke them in the block passed into a call of the
method. Read the method descriptions for the details.
If you override any of the document-attribute properties (listed under
) by overriding the related accessor methods, be aware that the UIKit framework can call these accessor methods on a background thread. Thus your overriding implementation must be thread safe.
